Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the mid-1970’s, Erno Rubik invented the
Rubik’s cube. But that doesn’t mean knew how to solve it. It took him a few moths  to figure
it out. By the time the first World Rubik’s Cube
Championships were held in 1982, The winner -- he could solve the cube in a
little less than 23 seconds. And these days?
[news montage of collin’s record] This is world record holder Collin Burns, and
today, we find out how he did it. [TITLES] “It could last another day; it could last
another few years. The previous record lasted for just over 2 years. But with single solve,
especially, you just need to get lucky. Or at least that’s a big part of it.” Collin tends to downplay his skills but it’s
worth noting there are two types of world records.
The way speedcubing competitions work is that volunteers scramble the cubes according to
instructions that are generated by a computer, so competitors all get the same scramble. They do 5 solves and their three middle scores
are averaged. So Collin holds the world record for a single
solve. But the world record for an average score
is held by a 19-year-old in Australia. Still, Collin’s record is a huge deal. At
the competition where we met up with him, kids were asking him for his autograph. He’s now being sponsored by a cube company
and by a cube retailer, which are paying for him to travel internationally. And he wants
people to know, you could do this too. “The biggest misconception about cubing
is that it’s difficult, which it really isn’t.”
Pop culture treats the Rubik’s cube like some sort of IQ test, but it’s not. At least
not anymore. “Generally average is much more impressive
because you have to be consistently fast.” Still, Collin’s record is a huge deal. At
the competition where we met up with him, other kids were asking him for autographs.
“are you that famous cube guy?” I recently bought a cube online and it came
with instructions for beginners. And if you memorize those, you can solve the cube in
a couple minutes. It helps to understand the design of the puzzle.
At first glance, it looks like a cube made out of cubes — right, three layers of nine. But if you look closer, you’ll see there
aren’t actually any cubes here. So that tells you that the corners will always be
corners, the edges will always be edges, and the middle pieces determine the color of that
face. Speedcubers will buy special cubes. They can
lubricate them and adjust the tension. But the real key to their speed is efficiency
- they’re looking several moves ahead, and they use fewer moves to get the same result. So there are 43 quintillion possible arrangements
for the cube. A few years back, some researchers borrowed
computing power from Google to find out that any scramble can be solved in 20 moves or
less. They call it God’s Number. But humans just aren’t that good. The beginners’ method that I learned uses
100 to 200 moves. Speedcubers use more around 50 to 60 moves.
And they can do that, in part, because of the knowledge gained by the previous generation
of speedcubers. When the cube first spread around the world
back in the 80s, people had to learn through trial and error. This was happening in a lot of math departments
and campus clubs. People were discovering the cube at the same time, and they were sharing
what they learned. The method Collin uses was developed by Jessica
Fridrich, an engineering professor who was a college student at the time. It starts with a cross on one of the faces.
And that face becomes the bottom layer. Then what they do is solve the corners of the bottom
layer and the middle layer simultaneously. “So, now you can see that all of this is
solved.” And for the final layer, they’re choosing
from dozens of algorithms that they’ve memorized. And those are sequences of moves that mess
up the cube temporarily to move certain pieces into place. And then put the rest of the cube
back where it was. The Rubik’s cube has made a comeback in
recent years along with that same ethic of sharing tips and strategies. So all the resources you need are there, there’s
just one other thing. Practice! This is Collin nearly 5 years ago. world records
are not built in a day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Any scramble can be solved in ___ moves or less.
Options: A. 20, B. 50, C. 100, D. 1,000
Correct Option: A

A virus, a parasite, or a bacterial infection, D. A combination of genetics and lifestyle factors Correct Option: A

It reveals that ulcers are caused by a single bacterial strain, D. It demonstrates that ulcers are a result of poor diet and lack of exercise Correct Option: B

Mucosal defense is the process by which the body produces bicarbonate, mucus, and phospholipids to maintain the integrity of its own lining Correct Option: D

We still have unanswered questions about why specific people develop ulcers at particular times, B. We do not fully understand the role of Helicobacter pylori in the development of ulcers, C. We do not know how to prevent the development of stomach ulcers, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1984, an enterprising Australian doctor
named Barry Marshall decided to take a risk. Too many of his patients were complaining
of severe abdominal pain due to stomach ulcers, which are sores in the lining
of the upper intestinal tract. At the time, few effective treatments
for ulcers existed, and many sufferers required
hospitalization or even surgery. Desperate for answers, Dr. Marshall swallowed a cloudy
broth of bacteria collected from the stomach
of one of his patients. Soon, Dr. Marshall was experiencing
the same abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting. Ten days later, a camera called 
an endoscope peered inside his insides. Marshall's stomach was teeming
with the same bacteria as his patient. He'd also developed gastritis,
or severe inflammation of the stomach, the hallmark precursor of ulcers. Dr. Marshall's idea challenged a misconception 
that still persists to this day: that ulcers are caused by stress, food, or too much stomach acid. Marshall thought the culprit
was bacterial infections. Initially, his idea was considered crazy by the brightest medical 
minds on the planet. But in 2005, he and Dr. Robin Warren
received the ultimate validation when they were awarded the Nobel
Prize for medicine. Our stomachs are J-shaped organs
with surprisingly intricate ecosystems awash in hormones and chemicals. The stomach is under constant attack
by digestive enzymes, bile, proteins, microbes, and the stomach's own acid. In response, it produces bicarbonate, mucus, and phospholipids called prostaglandins to maintain the integrity
of its own lining. This delicate balance is constantly
regulated and referred to as mucosal defense. Since the mid-1800s, doctors thought
stress alone caused most stomach ulcers. Patients were given antidepressants
or tranquilizers and told to visit health spas. This belief eventually shifted
to the related notion of spicy foods and stress as culprits. Yet no convincing study has ever
demonstrated that emotional upset, psychological distress, or spicy food directly causes ulcer disease. By the mid-20th century, it was widely
accepted that excess hydrochloric acid prompted the stomach to eat itself. Fervent proponents of this idea
were referred to as the acid mafia. The biggest hole in this theory
was that antiacids only provide temporary relief. We now know that some rare ulcers are indeed caused 
by too much hydrochloric acid. But they make up less than 1%
of all cases. Dr. Marshall and Dr. Warren pinpointed
a spiral-shaped bacteria called Helicobacter pylori,
or H. pylori, as the real offender. H. pylori is one of humanity's oldest
and most frequent companions, having joined us at least 50,000
years ago, and now found in 50% of people. Previously, we thought the stomach
was sterile on account of it being such an acidic,
hostile environment. Yet H. pylori survives the acidic turmoil
of the stomach with a variety of features that disrupt
mucosal defense in its favor. For example, it produces an enzyme
called urease that helps protect it from 
the surrounding gastric acid. H. pylori can make over 1,500 proteins, many of which are dedicated to maximizing
its virulence. We still have unanswered questions, like why specific people develop ulcers
at particular times. However, we do know individual genetics, other medical problems, use of certain medications, smoking, and the genetic diversity 
of Helicobacter strains all play a role. In particular, certain pain medications
used to reduce inflammation in joints have been discovered to work
with H. pylori to create more severe stomach ulcers. Dr. Marshall ended up being fine after
his famous, albeit dangerous, experiment. He ingested a course of antibiotics
similar to the ones taken now for ulcers. To be treated by simple antibiotics
is a modern triumph for a disease that previously 
needed surgery. Marshall's work also reminded us that
scientific progress is not always smooth. But there's value in trusting 
your proverbial, and sometimes literal, gut.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Prior to the discovery of Helicobacter pylori, which of the following were considered causes of peptic ulcers?
Options: A. Spicy foods, B. High stress lifestyles, C. Anxious dispositions, D. High acid levels, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the theorem that states for a right triangle, the square of one side plus the square of the other side is equal to the square of the hypotenuse? Options: A. Pythagoras' theorem, B. Euclid's theorem, C. The theorem of similarity, D. The Pythagorean theorem Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to the transcript, who are some of the people who came up with elegant proofs for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Only Euclid, B. Only James Garfield, C. Only Albert Einstein, D. Euclid, James Garfield, and Albert Einstein Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the name of the strategy used by Pythagoras in one of his proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Proof by rearrangement, B. Proof by induction, C. Proof by contradiction, D. Proof by analogy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the relationship between the areas of the squares produced by a rope stretched across the diagonal of a square, according to the earliest known Indian mathematical texts? Options: A. The area of the larger square is equal to the area of the smaller square, B. The area of the larger square is twice the area of the smaller square, C. The area of the larger square is half the area of the smaller square, D. The area of the larger square is three times the area of the smaller square Correct Option: B
Question 5: What principle was used by Euclid in one of his proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. The principle of similarity, B. The principle of congruence, C. The principle of proportionality, D. The principle of equivalence Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the geometric pattern used in one of the proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Tessellation, B. Mosaic, C. Pattern of similarity, D. Pattern of congruence Correct Option: A
Question 7: According to the transcript, how many proofs of the Pythagorean theorem are known? Options: A. More than 200, B. More than 300, C. More than 350, D. More than 400 Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the purpose of a proof in mathematics? Options: A. To demonstrate that a theorem is true for a specific case, B. To demonstrate that a theorem is true for all cases, C. To provide a visual representation of a theorem, D. To provide a logical explanation of a theorem Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, who is the American President who came up with an elegant proof for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. James Garfield, B. George Washington, C. Thomas Jefferson, D. Abraham Lincoln Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1984, an enterprising Australian doctor
named Barry Marshall decided to take a risk. Too many of his patients were complaining
of severe abdominal pain due to stomach ulcers, which are sores in the lining
of the upper intestinal tract. At the time, few effective treatments
for ulcers existed, and many sufferers required
hospitalization or even surgery. Desperate for answers, Dr. Marshall swallowed a cloudy
broth of bacteria collected from the stomach
of one of his patients. Soon, Dr. Marshall was experiencing
the same abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting. Ten days later, a camera called 
an endoscope peered inside his insides. Marshall's stomach was teeming
with the same bacteria as his patient. He'd also developed gastritis,
or severe inflammation of the stomach, the hallmark precursor of ulcers. Dr. Marshall's idea challenged a misconception 
that still persists to this day: that ulcers are caused by stress, food, or too much stomach acid. Marshall thought the culprit
was bacterial infections. Initially, his idea was considered crazy by the brightest medical 
minds on the planet. But in 2005, he and Dr. Robin Warren
received the ultimate validation when they were awarded the Nobel
Prize for medicine. Our stomachs are J-shaped organs
with surprisingly intricate ecosystems awash in hormones and chemicals. The stomach is under constant attack
by digestive enzymes, bile, proteins, microbes, and the stomach's own acid. In response, it produces bicarbonate, mucus, and phospholipids called prostaglandins to maintain the integrity
of its own lining. This delicate balance is constantly
regulated and referred to as mucosal defense. Since the mid-1800s, doctors thought
stress alone caused most stomach ulcers. Patients were given antidepressants
or tranquilizers and told to visit health spas. This belief eventually shifted
to the related notion of spicy foods and stress as culprits. Yet no convincing study has ever
demonstrated that emotional upset, psychological distress, or spicy food directly causes ulcer disease. By the mid-20th century, it was widely
accepted that excess hydrochloric acid prompted the stomach to eat itself. Fervent proponents of this idea
were referred to as the acid mafia. The biggest hole in this theory
was that antiacids only provide temporary relief. We now know that some rare ulcers are indeed caused 
by too much hydrochloric acid. But they make up less than 1%
of all cases. Dr. Marshall and Dr. Warren pinpointed
a spiral-shaped bacteria called Helicobacter pylori,
or H. pylori, as the real offender. H. pylori is one of humanity's oldest
and most frequent companions, having joined us at least 50,000
years ago, and now found in 50% of people. Previously, we thought the stomach
was sterile on account of it being such an acidic,
hostile environment. Yet H. pylori survives the acidic turmoil
of the stomach with a variety of features that disrupt
mucosal defense in its favor. For example, it produces an enzyme
called urease that helps protect it from 
the surrounding gastric acid. H. pylori can make over 1,500 proteins, many of which are dedicated to maximizing
its virulence. We still have unanswered questions, like why specific people develop ulcers
at particular times. However, we do know individual genetics, other medical problems, use of certain medications, smoking, and the genetic diversity 
of Helicobacter strains all play a role. In particular, certain pain medications
used to reduce inflammation in joints have been discovered to work
with H. pylori to create more severe stomach ulcers. Dr. Marshall ended up being fine after
his famous, albeit dangerous, experiment. He ingested a course of antibiotics
similar to the ones taken now for ulcers. To be treated by simple antibiotics
is a modern triumph for a disease that previously 
needed surgery. Marshall's work also reminded us that
scientific progress is not always smooth. But there's value in trusting 
your proverbial, and sometimes literal, gut.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the context of peptic ulcer disease, mucosal defense refers to which concept?
Options: A. The interplay of structural and chemical factors that maintain the integrity and appropriate functioning of the lining of the stomach, B. The numerous immune cells that are use to disrupt the protein shell of Helicobacter pylori, C. The intra-cellular inflammatory cascade that emerges to minimize the noxious effects of an ulcer once it has formed, D. The dramatic rise in base levels to counteract the corrosive effects of excess stomach acid
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the theorem that states for a right triangle, the square of one side plus the square of the other side is equal to the square of the hypotenuse? Options: A. Pythagoras' theorem, B. Euclid's theorem, C. The theorem of similarity, D. The Pythagorean theorem Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to the transcript, who are some of the people who came up with elegant proofs for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Only Euclid, B. Only James Garfield, C. Only Albert Einstein, D. Euclid, James Garfield, and Albert Einstein Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the name of the strategy used by Pythagoras in one of his proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Proof by rearrangement, B. Proof by induction, C. Proof by contradiction, D. Proof by analogy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the relationship between the areas of the squares produced by a rope stretched across the diagonal of a square, according to the earliest known Indian mathematical texts? Options: A. The area of the larger square is equal to the area of the smaller square, B. The area of the larger square is twice the area of the smaller square, C. The area of the larger square is half the area of the smaller square, D. The area of the larger square is three times the area of the smaller square Correct Option: B
Question 5: What principle was used by Euclid in one of his proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. The principle of similarity, B. The principle of congruence, C. The principle of proportionality, D. The principle of equivalence Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the geometric pattern used in one of the proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Tessellation, B. Mosaic, C. Pattern of similarity, D. Pattern of congruence Correct Option: A
Question 7: According to the transcript, how many proofs of the Pythagorean theorem are known? Options: A. More than 200, B. More than 300, C. More than 350, D. More than 400 Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the purpose of a proof in mathematics? Options: A. To demonstrate that a theorem is true for a specific case, B. To demonstrate that a theorem is true for all cases, C. To provide a visual representation of a theorem, D. To provide a logical explanation of a theorem Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, who is the American President who came up with an elegant proof for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. James Garfield, B. George Washington, C. Thomas Jefferson, D. Abraham Lincoln Correct Option: A
Question 10: Who is the 12-year-old boy who came up with a proof for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Albert Einstein, B. Archimedes, C. Euclid, D. Pythagoras Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following factors most influences when Helicobacter pylori prompts the development of ulcers?

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the theorem that states for a right triangle, the square of one side plus the square of the other side is equal to the square of the hypotenuse? Options: A. Pythagoras' theorem, B. Euclid's theorem, C. The theorem of similarity, D. The Pythagorean theorem Correct Option: D
Question 2: According to the transcript, who are some of the people who came up with elegant proofs for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Only Euclid, B. Only James Garfield, C. Only Albert Einstein, D. Euclid, James Garfield, and Albert Einstein Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the name of the strategy used by Pythagoras in one of his proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Proof by rearrangement, B. Proof by induction, C. Proof by contradiction, D. Proof by analogy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the relationship between the areas of the squares produced by a rope stretched across the diagonal of a square, according to the earliest known Indian mathematical texts? Options: A. The area of the larger square is equal to the area of the smaller square, B. The area of the larger square is twice the area of the smaller square, C. The area of the larger square is half the area of the smaller square, D. The area of the larger square is three times the area of the smaller square Correct Option: B
Question 5: What principle was used by Euclid in one of his proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. The principle of similarity, B. The principle of congruence, C. The principle of proportionality, D. The principle of equivalence Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the geometric pattern used in one of the proofs of the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Tessellation, B. Mosaic, C. Pattern of similarity, D. Pattern of congruence Correct Option: A
Question 7: According to the transcript, how many proofs of the Pythagorean theorem are known? Options: A. More than 200, B. More than 300, C. More than 350, D. More than 400 Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the purpose of a proof in mathematics? Options: A. To demonstrate that a theorem is true for a specific case, B. To demonstrate that a theorem is true for all cases, C. To provide a visual representation of a theorem, D. To provide a logical explanation of a theorem Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, who is the American President who came up with an elegant proof for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. James Garfield, B. George Washington, C. Thomas Jefferson, D. Abraham Lincoln Correct Option: A
Question 10: Who is the 12-year-old boy who came up with a proof for the Pythagorean theorem? Options: A. Albert Einstein, B. Archimedes, C. Euclid, D. Pythagoras Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
During the warmer months,
especially at night during the full moon, horseshoe crabs emerge 
from the sea to spawn. Waiting for them are teams
of lab workers who capture the horseshoe crabs
by the hundreds of thousands, take them to labs, harvest their cerulean blood, then return them to the sea. Oddly enough, we capture horseshoe crabs
on the beach because that's the only place
we know we can find them. A female horseshoe crab lays as many
as 20 batches of up to 4,000 eggs on her annual visit to the beach. When the eggs hatch, the juvenile horseshoe crabs
often stay near shore, periodically shedding their shells
as they grow. Once they leave 
these shallow waters, they don't return until they
reach sexual maturity ten years later. Despite our best efforts, we don't
know where they spend those years. Though we've spotted the occasional 
horseshoe crab as deep as 200 meters below
the ocean's surface, we only see large groups of adults
when they come ashore to spawn. Horseshoe crab blood contains
cells called amebocytes that protect them 
from infection by viruses, fungi, and bacteria. Amebocytes form gels around
these invaders to prevent them from spreading infections. This isn't unusual. All animals have protective 
immune systems. But horseshoe crab amebocytes
are exceptionally sensitive to bacterial endotoxins. Endotoxins are molecules
from the cell walls of certain bacteria, including E. coli. Large amounts of them are released
when bacterial cells die, and they can make us sick
if they enter the blood stream. Many of the medicines and medical devices
we rely on can become contaminated, so we have to test them
before they touch our blood. We do have tests called Gram stains
that detect bacteria, but they can't recognize endotoxins which can be there even when
bacteria aren't present. So scientists use an extract called LAL produced from harvested 
horseshoe crab blood to test for endotoxins. They add LAL to a medicine sample,
and if gels form, bacterial endotoxins are present. Today, the LAL test is used so widely that millions of people who've
never seen a horseshoe crab have been protected by their blood. If you've ever had an injection,
that probably includes you. How did horseshoe crabs end up
with such special blood? Like other invertebrates, the horseshoe crab has an open
circulatory system. This means their blood isn't contained
in blood vessels, like ours. Instead, horseshoe crab blood
flows freely through the body cavity and comes in direct contact with tissues. If bacteria enters their blood,
it can quickly spread over a large area. Pair this vulnerability with the horseshoe crab's bacteria-filled 
ocean and shoreline habitats, and it's easy to see why they need
such a sensitive immune response. Horseshoe crabs survived 
mass extinction events that wiped out over 90% of life on Earth
and killed off the dinosaurs, but they're not invincible. And the biggest disruptions they've faced
in millions of years come from us. Studies have shown that up to
15% of horseshoe crabs die in the process of having
their blood harvested. And recent research suggests
this number may be even higher. Researchers have also observed
fewer females returning to spawn at some of the most harvested areas. Our impact on horseshoe crabs extends
beyond the biomedical industry, too. Coastal development 
destroys spawning sites, and horseshoe crabs are also
killed for fishing bait. There's ample evidence that
their populations are shrinking. Some researchers have started working to synthesize horseshoe crab 
blood in the lab. For now, we're unlikely to stop
our beach trips, but hopefully, a synthetic alternative
will someday eliminate our reliance on the blood of these ancient creatures.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where do adult horseshoe crabs live?
Options: A. On the beach, B. In the shallows, C. In the deep sea, D. We don’t know for sure
Correct Option: D

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
During the warmer months,
especially at night during the full moon, horseshoe crabs emerge 
from the sea to spawn. Waiting for them are teams
of lab workers who capture the horseshoe crabs
by the hundreds of thousands, take them to labs, harvest their cerulean blood, then return them to the sea. Oddly enough, we capture horseshoe crabs
on the beach because that's the only place
we know we can find them. A female horseshoe crab lays as many
as 20 batches of up to 4,000 eggs on her annual visit to the beach. When the eggs hatch, the juvenile horseshoe crabs
often stay near shore, periodically shedding their shells
as they grow. Once they leave 
these shallow waters, they don't return until they
reach sexual maturity ten years later. Despite our best efforts, we don't
know where they spend those years. Though we've spotted the occasional 
horseshoe crab as deep as 200 meters below
the ocean's surface, we only see large groups of adults
when they come ashore to spawn. Horseshoe crab blood contains
cells called amebocytes that protect them 
from infection by viruses, fungi, and bacteria. Amebocytes form gels around
these invaders to prevent them from spreading infections. This isn't unusual. All animals have protective 
immune systems. But horseshoe crab amebocytes
are exceptionally sensitive to bacterial endotoxins. Endotoxins are molecules
from the cell walls of certain bacteria, including E. coli. Large amounts of them are released
when bacterial cells die, and they can make us sick
if they enter the blood stream. Many of the medicines and medical devices
we rely on can become contaminated, so we have to test them
before they touch our blood. We do have tests called Gram stains
that detect bacteria, but they can't recognize endotoxins which can be there even when
bacteria aren't present. So scientists use an extract called LAL produced from harvested 
horseshoe crab blood to test for endotoxins. They add LAL to a medicine sample,
and if gels form, bacterial endotoxins are present. Today, the LAL test is used so widely that millions of people who've
never seen a horseshoe crab have been protected by their blood. If you've ever had an injection,
that probably includes you. How did horseshoe crabs end up
with such special blood? Like other invertebrates, the horseshoe crab has an open
circulatory system. This means their blood isn't contained
in blood vessels, like ours. Instead, horseshoe crab blood
flows freely through the body cavity and comes in direct contact with tissues. If bacteria enters their blood,
it can quickly spread over a large area. Pair this vulnerability with the horseshoe crab's bacteria-filled 
ocean and shoreline habitats, and it's easy to see why they need
such a sensitive immune response. Horseshoe crabs survived 
mass extinction events that wiped out over 90% of life on Earth
and killed off the dinosaurs, but they're not invincible. And the biggest disruptions they've faced
in millions of years come from us. Studies have shown that up to
15% of horseshoe crabs die in the process of having
their blood harvested. And recent research suggests
this number may be even higher. Researchers have also observed
fewer females returning to spawn at some of the most harvested areas. Our impact on horseshoe crabs extends
beyond the biomedical industry, too. Coastal development 
destroys spawning sites, and horseshoe crabs are also
killed for fishing bait. There's ample evidence that
their populations are shrinking. Some researchers have started working to synthesize horseshoe crab 
blood in the lab. For now, we're unlikely to stop
our beach trips, but hopefully, a synthetic alternative
will someday eliminate our reliance on the blood of these ancient creatures.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: We use amebocytes from horseshoe crab blood to test for:
Options: A. Viruses, B. Bacteria, C. Bacterial endotoxins, D. Fungi, E. Bacteria and bacterial endotoxins, F. All of the above
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
During the warmer months,
especially at night during the full moon, horseshoe crabs emerge 
from the sea to spawn. Waiting for them are teams
of lab workers who capture the horseshoe crabs
by the hundreds of thousands, take them to labs, harvest their cerulean blood, then return them to the sea. Oddly enough, we capture horseshoe crabs
on the beach because that's the only place
we know we can find them. A female horseshoe crab lays as many
as 20 batches of up to 4,000 eggs on her annual visit to the beach. When the eggs hatch, the juvenile horseshoe crabs
often stay near shore, periodically shedding their shells
as they grow. Once they leave 
these shallow waters, they don't return until they
reach sexual maturity ten years later. Despite our best efforts, we don't
know where they spend those years. Though we've spotted the occasional 
horseshoe crab as deep as 200 meters below
the ocean's surface, we only see large groups of adults
when they come ashore to spawn. Horseshoe crab blood contains
cells called amebocytes that protect them 
from infection by viruses, fungi, and bacteria. Amebocytes form gels around
these invaders to prevent them from spreading infections. This isn't unusual. All animals have protective 
immune systems. But horseshoe crab amebocytes
are exceptionally sensitive to bacterial endotoxins. Endotoxins are molecules
from the cell walls of certain bacteria, including E. coli. Large amounts of them are released
when bacterial cells die, and they can make us sick
if they enter the blood stream. Many of the medicines and medical devices
we rely on can become contaminated, so we have to test them
before they touch our blood. We do have tests called Gram stains
that detect bacteria, but they can't recognize endotoxins which can be there even when
bacteria aren't present. So scientists use an extract called LAL produced from harvested 
horseshoe crab blood to test for endotoxins. They add LAL to a medicine sample,
and if gels form, bacterial endotoxins are present. Today, the LAL test is used so widely that millions of people who've
never seen a horseshoe crab have been protected by their blood. If you've ever had an injection,
that probably includes you. How did horseshoe crabs end up
with such special blood? Like other invertebrates, the horseshoe crab has an open
circulatory system. This means their blood isn't contained
in blood vessels, like ours. Instead, horseshoe crab blood
flows freely through the body cavity and comes in direct contact with tissues. If bacteria enters their blood,
it can quickly spread over a large area. Pair this vulnerability with the horseshoe crab's bacteria-filled 
ocean and shoreline habitats, and it's easy to see why they need
such a sensitive immune response. Horseshoe crabs survived 
mass extinction events that wiped out over 90% of life on Earth
and killed off the dinosaurs, but they're not invincible. And the biggest disruptions they've faced
in millions of years come from us. Studies have shown that up to
15% of horseshoe crabs die in the process of having
their blood harvested. And recent research suggests
this number may be even higher. Researchers have also observed
fewer females returning to spawn at some of the most harvested areas. Our impact on horseshoe crabs extends
beyond the biomedical industry, too. Coastal development 
destroys spawning sites, and horseshoe crabs are also
killed for fishing bait. There's ample evidence that
their populations are shrinking. Some researchers have started working to synthesize horseshoe crab 
blood in the lab. For now, we're unlikely to stop
our beach trips, but hopefully, a synthetic alternative
will someday eliminate our reliance on the blood of these ancient creatures.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: LAL reveals the presence of contaminants by:
Options: A. Forming gels, B. Changing color, C. Changing temperature, D. Developing a grainy texture
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was the speaker brought up, according to the transcript? Options: A. In India, B. In Kenya, C. Near Wembley, D. In London Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the main argument against identity myths presented by the speaker? Options: A. They are necessary for human development., B. They are based on myths and typically about ancient, primordial origins., C. They make us feel secure and give us a sense of belonging., D. They are harmless and do not affect our lives. Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the speaker, what is the main purpose of Salafi jihadi groups when they take over an area? Options: A. To establish a democratic government and promote economic development., B. To protect human rights and promote social justice., C. To destroy existing Muslim institutions, dictate the spaces that women may go, and control people internally., D. To promote a more inclusive and tolerant society. Correct Option: C
Question 4: The speaker argues that cultures are processes, not things. What does this imply? Options: A. Cultures are static and unchanging., B. Cultures are solely the property of those who have a political stake in them., C. Cultures are impermanent, messy, and dynamic., D. Cultures are only about language, food, clothing, and music. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the speaker's view on the importance of origin stories and identity myths? Options: A. They are essential for human development and should be preserved., B. They are based on myths and do not reflect the complexity of humanity., C. They are harmless and do not affect our lives., D. They are necessary for social and economic progress. Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between tradition and history? Options: A. Tradition is old and permanent, while history is recent and changing., B. Tradition is history condensed into a nice story., C. Tradition is about the past, while history is about the present., D. Tradition is about culture, while history is about politics. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the speaker's view on the idea of a "pure" ethnicity or national culture? Options: A. It is essential for human development and should be preserved., B. It is a myth and does not reflect the complexity of humanity., C. It is necessary for social and economic progress., D. It is harmless and does not affect our lives. Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the speaker, what is the main reason why people join Al Qaeda or Islamic State? Options: A. They are seeking economic opportunities or social and economic justice., B. They are seeking to reject their backgrounds and become someone else., C. They are seeking to protect human rights and promote social justice., D. They are seeking to establish a democratic government. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the speaker's view on the importance of being skeptical about origin stories and identity myths? Options: A. It is essential for human development and should be preserved., B. It is necessary for social and economic progress., C. It is harmless and does not affect our lives., D. It allows us to challenge ourselves to think creatively about each other and our future. Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the speaker, what is the main lesson we can learn from the story of Ibn Rushd? Options: A. We should preserve traditional values and cultural practices., B. We should reject reason and evidence in favor of divine truth., C. We should separate religious life from social and political life., D. We should promote economic development and reduce poverty. Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is the speaker's view on the idea of a "radically different idea of humanity"? Options: A. It is a threat to human development and should be rejected., B. It is a myth and does not reflect the complexity of humanity., C. It is necessary for social and economic progress., D. It allows us to challenge ourselves to think creatively about each other and our future. Correct Option: D
Question 12: According to the speaker, what is the main reason why people cling to pure identities? Options: A. They are seeking to establish a democratic government., B. They are seeking to protect human rights and promote social justice., C. They are seeking to reject their backgrounds and become someone else., D. They are seeking to preserve traditional values and cultural practices. Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the speaker's view on the importance of tradition? Options: A. It is essential for human development and should be preserved., B. It is necessary for social and economic progress., C. It is a myth and does not reflect the complexity of humanity., D. It is a way to understand the past and learn from it. Correct Option: D
Question 14: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between fundamentalism and secularism? Options: A. Fundamentalism is about preserving traditional values and cultural practices, while secularism is about rejecting reason and evidence., B. Fundamentalism is about rejecting reason and evidence, while secularism is about preserving traditional values and cultural practices., C. Fundamentalism is about imposing laws and boundaries, while secularism is about separating religious life from social and political life., D. Fundamentalism is about promoting economic development and reducing poverty, while secularism is about protecting human rights and promoting social justice. Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the speaker's view on the idea of a "pure" culture? Options: A. It is essential for human development and should be preserved., B. It is a myth and does not reflect the complexity of humanity., C. It is necessary for social and economic progress., D. It is a way to understand the past and learn from it. Correct Option: B
Question 16: According to the speaker, what is the main purpose of origin myths? Options: A. To establish a democratic government and promote economic development., B. To protect human rights and promote social justice., C. To create a sense of belonging and security., D. To promote a more inclusive and tolerant society. Correct Option: C
Question 17: What is the speaker's view on the idea of a "born again" vision? Options: A. It is a positive and uplifting concept., B. It is a negative and oppressive concept., C. It is a neutral concept that has no impact on society., D. It is a concept that allows people to reject their backgrounds and become someone else. Correct Option: D
Question 18: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between a "pure" culture and a "messy" culture? Options: A. A "pure" culture is static and unchanging, while a "messy" culture is dynamic and evolving., B. A "pure" culture is about imposing laws and boundaries, while a "messy" culture is about promoting social justice and human rights., C. A "pure" culture is about rejecting reason and evidence, while a "messy" culture is about embracing complexity and diversity., D. A "pure" culture is about preserving traditional values and cultural practices, while a "messy" culture is about promoting economic development and reducing poverty. Correct Option: C
Question 19: What is the speaker's view on the idea of a "radical" idea of humanity? Options: A. It is a threat to human development and should be rejected., B. It is a myth and does not reflect the complexity of humanity., C. It is necessary for social and economic progress., D. It allows us to challenge ourselves to think creatively about each other and our future. Correct Option: D

They are seeking to protect human rights and promote social justice., C. They are seeking to reject their backgrounds and become someone else., D. They are seeking to preserve traditional values and cultural practices. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
During the warmer months,
especially at night during the full moon, horseshoe crabs emerge 
from the sea to spawn. Waiting for them are teams
of lab workers who capture the horseshoe crabs
by the hundreds of thousands, take them to labs, harvest their cerulean blood, then return them to the sea. Oddly enough, we capture horseshoe crabs
on the beach because that's the only place
we know we can find them. A female horseshoe crab lays as many
as 20 batches of up to 4,000 eggs on her annual visit to the beach. When the eggs hatch, the juvenile horseshoe crabs
often stay near shore, periodically shedding their shells
as they grow. Once they leave 
these shallow waters, they don't return until they
reach sexual maturity ten years later. Despite our best efforts, we don't
know where they spend those years. Though we've spotted the occasional 
horseshoe crab as deep as 200 meters below
the ocean's surface, we only see large groups of adults
when they come ashore to spawn. Horseshoe crab blood contains
cells called amebocytes that protect them 
from infection by viruses, fungi, and bacteria. Amebocytes form gels around
these invaders to prevent them from spreading infections. This isn't unusual. All animals have protective 
immune systems. But horseshoe crab amebocytes
are exceptionally sensitive to bacterial endotoxins. Endotoxins are molecules
from the cell walls of certain bacteria, including E. coli. Large amounts of them are released
when bacterial cells die, and they can make us sick
if they enter the blood stream. Many of the medicines and medical devices
we rely on can become contaminated, so we have to test them
before they touch our blood. We do have tests called Gram stains
that detect bacteria, but they can't recognize endotoxins which can be there even when
bacteria aren't present. So scientists use an extract called LAL produced from harvested 
horseshoe crab blood to test for endotoxins. They add LAL to a medicine sample,
and if gels form, bacterial endotoxins are present. Today, the LAL test is used so widely that millions of people who've
never seen a horseshoe crab have been protected by their blood. If you've ever had an injection,
that probably includes you. How did horseshoe crabs end up
with such special blood? Like other invertebrates, the horseshoe crab has an open
circulatory system. This means their blood isn't contained
in blood vessels, like ours. Instead, horseshoe crab blood
flows freely through the body cavity and comes in direct contact with tissues. If bacteria enters their blood,
it can quickly spread over a large area. Pair this vulnerability with the horseshoe crab's bacteria-filled 
ocean and shoreline habitats, and it's easy to see why they need
such a sensitive immune response. Horseshoe crabs survived 
mass extinction events that wiped out over 90% of life on Earth
and killed off the dinosaurs, but they're not invincible. And the biggest disruptions they've faced
in millions of years come from us. Studies have shown that up to
15% of horseshoe crabs die in the process of having
their blood harvested. And recent research suggests
this number may be even higher. Researchers have also observed
fewer females returning to spawn at some of the most harvested areas. Our impact on horseshoe crabs extends
beyond the biomedical industry, too. Coastal development 
destroys spawning sites, and horseshoe crabs are also
killed for fishing bait. There's ample evidence that
their populations are shrinking. Some researchers have started working to synthesize horseshoe crab 
blood in the lab. For now, we're unlikely to stop
our beach trips, but hopefully, a synthetic alternative
will someday eliminate our reliance on the blood of these ancient creatures.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Horseshoe crabs have which of the following?
Options: A. A closed circulatory system, B. An open circulatory system, C. Veins, D. An open circulatory system and veins
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
During the warmer months,
especially at night during the full moon, horseshoe crabs emerge 
from the sea to spawn. Waiting for them are teams
of lab workers who capture the horseshoe crabs
by the hundreds of thousands, take them to labs, harvest their cerulean blood, then return them to the sea. Oddly enough, we capture horseshoe crabs
on the beach because that's the only place
we know we can find them. A female horseshoe crab lays as many
as 20 batches of up to 4,000 eggs on her annual visit to the beach. When the eggs hatch, the juvenile horseshoe crabs
often stay near shore, periodically shedding their shells
as they grow. Once they leave 
these shallow waters, they don't return until they
reach sexual maturity ten years later. Despite our best efforts, we don't
know where they spend those years. Though we've spotted the occasional 
horseshoe crab as deep as 200 meters below
the ocean's surface, we only see large groups of adults
when they come ashore to spawn. Horseshoe crab blood contains
cells called amebocytes that protect them 
from infection by viruses, fungi, and bacteria. Amebocytes form gels around
these invaders to prevent them from spreading infections. This isn't unusual. All animals have protective 
immune systems. But horseshoe crab amebocytes
are exceptionally sensitive to bacterial endotoxins. Endotoxins are molecules
from the cell walls of certain bacteria, including E. coli. Large amounts of them are released
when bacterial cells die, and they can make us sick
if they enter the blood stream. Many of the medicines and medical devices
we rely on can become contaminated, so we have to test them
before they touch our blood. We do have tests called Gram stains
that detect bacteria, but they can't recognize endotoxins which can be there even when
bacteria aren't present. So scientists use an extract called LAL produced from harvested 
horseshoe crab blood to test for endotoxins. They add LAL to a medicine sample,
and if gels form, bacterial endotoxins are present. Today, the LAL test is used so widely that millions of people who've
never seen a horseshoe crab have been protected by their blood. If you've ever had an injection,
that probably includes you. How did horseshoe crabs end up
with such special blood? Like other invertebrates, the horseshoe crab has an open
circulatory system. This means their blood isn't contained
in blood vessels, like ours. Instead, horseshoe crab blood
flows freely through the body cavity and comes in direct contact with tissues. If bacteria enters their blood,
it can quickly spread over a large area. Pair this vulnerability with the horseshoe crab's bacteria-filled 
ocean and shoreline habitats, and it's easy to see why they need
such a sensitive immune response. Horseshoe crabs survived 
mass extinction events that wiped out over 90% of life on Earth
and killed off the dinosaurs, but they're not invincible. And the biggest disruptions they've faced
in millions of years come from us. Studies have shown that up to
15% of horseshoe crabs die in the process of having
their blood harvested. And recent research suggests
this number may be even higher. Researchers have also observed
fewer females returning to spawn at some of the most harvested areas. Our impact on horseshoe crabs extends
beyond the biomedical industry, too. Coastal development 
destroys spawning sites, and horseshoe crabs are also
killed for fishing bait. There's ample evidence that
their populations are shrinking. Some researchers have started working to synthesize horseshoe crab 
blood in the lab. For now, we're unlikely to stop
our beach trips, but hopefully, a synthetic alternative
will someday eliminate our reliance on the blood of these ancient creatures.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of horseshoe crabs die while having their blood harvested?
Options: A. 5% or less, B. Estimates vary from 25% to 75%, C. Studies show about 15%, D. 40%
Correct Option: C

Options: A. 5% or less, B. 10-20%, C. Studies show about 15%, D. 25% or more

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The universe is bustling with matter
and energy. Even in the vast apparent emptiness
of intergalactic space, there's one hydrogen atom per cubic meter. That's not the mention 
a barrage of particles and electromagnetic radiation passing every which way from stars,
galaxies, and into black holes. There's even radiation left over
from the Big Bang. So is there such thing as a total
absence of everything? This isn't just a thought experiment. Empty spaces, or vacuums,
are incredibly useful. Inside our homes, 
most vacuum cleaners work by using a fan to create a low-pressure
relatively empty area that sucks matter in to fill the void. But that's far from empty. There's still plenty of matter
bouncing around. Manufacturers rely on more thorough,
sealed vacuums for all sorts of purposes. That includes vacuum-packed food
that stays fresh longer, and the vacuums inside early light bulbs
that protected filaments from degrading. These vacuums are generally created
with some version of what a vacuum cleaner does using high-powered pumps that create
enough suction to remove as many stray atoms as possible. But the best of these industrial processes tends to leave hundreds 
of millions of atoms per cubic centimeter of space. That isn't empty enough
for scientists who work on experiments, like the Large Hadron Collider, where particle beams need to circulate
at close to the speed of light for up to ten hours without hitting
any stray atoms. So how do they create a vacuum? The LHC's pipes are made of materials,
like stainless steel, that don't release any 
of their own molecules and are lined with a special coating
to absorb stray gases. Raising the temperature 
to 200 degrees Celsius burns off any moisture, and hundreds of vacuum pumps take
two weeks to trap enough gas and debris out of the pipes for the collider's
incredibly sensitive experiments. Even with all this, the Large Hadron Collider
isn't a perfect vacuum. In the emptiest places, there are still about 100,000 particles 
per cubic centimeter. But let's say an experiment like that
could somehow get every last atom out. There's still an unfathomably huge
amount of radiation all around us that can pass right through
the walls. Every second, about 50 muons
from cosmic rays, 10 million neutrinos coming directly
from the Big Bang, 30 million photons from the cosmic
microwave background, and 300 trillion neutrinos
from the Sun pass through your body. It is possible to shield
vacuum chambers with substances, including water, that absorb and reflect this radiation, except for neutrinos. Let's say you've somehow removed
all of the atoms and blocked all of the radiation. Is the space now totally empty? Actually, no. All space is filled with what 
physicists call quantum fields. What we think of as subatomic particles, electrons and photons and their relatives, are actually vibrations 
in a quantum fabric that extends throughout the universe. And because of a physical law called
the Heisenberg Principle, these fields never stop oscillating, even without any particles 
to set off the ripples. They always have some minimum fluctuation
called a vacuum fluctuation. This means they have energy,
a huge amount of it. Because Einstein's equations tell us
that mass and energy are equivalent, the quantum fluctuations in every
cubic meter of space have an energy that corresponds
to a mass of about four protons. In other words, the seemingly empty space
inside your vacuum would actually weigh a small amount. Quantum fluctuations have existed since
the earliest moments of the universe. In the moments after the Big Bang, as the universe expanded, they were amplified and stretched out
to cosmic scales. Cosmologists believe that these original
quantum fluctuations were the seeds of everything
we see today: galaxies and the entire large scale
structure of the universe, as well as planets and solar systems. They're also the center of one of the
greatest scientific mysteries of our time because according to the current theories, the quantum fluctuations 
in the vacuum of space ought to have 120 orders of magnitude
more energy than we observe. Solving the mystery of that missing energy may entirely rewrite our understanding
of physics and the universe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What types of particles from cosmic sources go through your body most frequently?
Options: A. Neutrinos, muons, photons, B. Protons and pions only, C. Electrons and quarks only, D. Alpha-, beta-, and gamma-rays
Correct Option: A

and energy. Even in the vast apparent emptiness

a barrage of particles and electromagnetic radiation passing every which way from stars,

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The universe is bustling with matter
and energy. Even in the vast apparent emptiness
of intergalactic space, there's one hydrogen atom per cubic meter. That's not the mention 
a barrage of particles and electromagnetic radiation passing every which way from stars,
galaxies, and into black holes. There's even radiation left over
from the Big Bang. So is there such thing as a total
absence of everything? This isn't just a thought experiment. Empty spaces, or vacuums,
are incredibly useful. Inside our homes, 
most vacuum cleaners work by using a fan to create a low-pressure
relatively empty area that sucks matter in to fill the void. But that's far from empty. There's still plenty of matter
bouncing around. Manufacturers rely on more thorough,
sealed vacuums for all sorts of purposes. That includes vacuum-packed food
that stays fresh longer, and the vacuums inside early light bulbs
that protected filaments from degrading. These vacuums are generally created
with some version of what a vacuum cleaner does using high-powered pumps that create
enough suction to remove as many stray atoms as possible. But the best of these industrial processes tends to leave hundreds 
of millions of atoms per cubic centimeter of space. That isn't empty enough
for scientists who work on experiments, like the Large Hadron Collider, where particle beams need to circulate
at close to the speed of light for up to ten hours without hitting
any stray atoms. So how do they create a vacuum? The LHC's pipes are made of materials,
like stainless steel, that don't release any 
of their own molecules and are lined with a special coating
to absorb stray gases. Raising the temperature 
to 200 degrees Celsius burns off any moisture, and hundreds of vacuum pumps take
two weeks to trap enough gas and debris out of the pipes for the collider's
incredibly sensitive experiments. Even with all this, the Large Hadron Collider
isn't a perfect vacuum. In the emptiest places, there are still about 100,000 particles 
per cubic centimeter. But let's say an experiment like that
could somehow get every last atom out. There's still an unfathomably huge
amount of radiation all around us that can pass right through
the walls. Every second, about 50 muons
from cosmic rays, 10 million neutrinos coming directly
from the Big Bang, 30 million photons from the cosmic
microwave background, and 300 trillion neutrinos
from the Sun pass through your body. It is possible to shield
vacuum chambers with substances, including water, that absorb and reflect this radiation, except for neutrinos. Let's say you've somehow removed
all of the atoms and blocked all of the radiation. Is the space now totally empty? Actually, no. All space is filled with what 
physicists call quantum fields. What we think of as subatomic particles, electrons and photons and their relatives, are actually vibrations 
in a quantum fabric that extends throughout the universe. And because of a physical law called
the Heisenberg Principle, these fields never stop oscillating, even without any particles 
to set off the ripples. They always have some minimum fluctuation
called a vacuum fluctuation. This means they have energy,
a huge amount of it. Because Einstein's equations tell us
that mass and energy are equivalent, the quantum fluctuations in every
cubic meter of space have an energy that corresponds
to a mass of about four protons. In other words, the seemingly empty space
inside your vacuum would actually weigh a small amount. Quantum fluctuations have existed since
the earliest moments of the universe. In the moments after the Big Bang, as the universe expanded, they were amplified and stretched out
to cosmic scales. Cosmologists believe that these original
quantum fluctuations were the seeds of everything
we see today: galaxies and the entire large scale
structure of the universe, as well as planets and solar systems. They're also the center of one of the
greatest scientific mysteries of our time because according to the current theories, the quantum fluctuations 
in the vacuum of space ought to have 120 orders of magnitude
more energy than we observe. Solving the mystery of that missing energy may entirely rewrite our understanding
of physics and the universe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Quantum fields:
Options: A. Have existed since the earliest moments of the universe, B. Fill all space even though it may appear empty, C. Extend throughout the universe, D. Continuously oscillate, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

Warning: No valid match index found in response for Ground Truth Set 17, Question 5
Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What do Euclid, twelve-year-old Einstein, and American President James Garfield
have in common? They all came up with elegant
proofs for the famous Pythagorean theorem, the rule that says for a right triangle, the square of one side plus
the square of the other side is equal to the square of the hypotenuse. In other words, a²+b²=c². This statement is one of the most
fundamental rules of geometry, and the basis for practical applications, like constructing stable buildings
and triangulating GPS coordinates. The theorem is named for Pythagoras, a Greek philosopher and mathematician
in the 6th century B.C., but it was known more than a
thousand years earlier. A Babylonian tablet from around 1800 B.C.
lists 15 sets of numbers that satisfy the theorem. Some historians speculate 
that Ancient Egyptian surveyors used one such set of numbers, 3, 4, 5,
to make square corners. The theory is that surveyors could stretch
a knotted rope with twelve equal segments to form a triangle with sides of length
3, 4 and 5. According to the converse
of the Pythagorean theorem, that has to make a right triangle, and, therefore, a square corner. And the earliest known 
Indian mathematical texts written between 800 and 600 B.C. state that a rope stretched across
the diagonal of a square produces a square twice as large
as the original one. That relationship can be derived
from the Pythagorean theorem. But how do we know 
that the theorem is true for every right triangle 
on a flat surface, not just the ones these mathematicians
and surveyors knew about? Because we can prove it. Proofs use existing mathematical rules
and logic to demonstrate that a theorem
must hold true all the time. One classic proof often attributed
to Pythagoras himself uses a strategy called 
proof by rearrangement. Take four identical right triangles
with side lengths a and b and hypotenuse length c. Arrange them so that their hypotenuses
form a tilted square. The area of that square is c². Now rearrange the triangles
into two rectangles, leaving smaller squares on either side. The areas of those squares
are a² and b². Here's the key. The total area of 
the figure didn't change, and the areas of the triangles
didn't change. So the empty space in one, c² must be equal to 
the empty space in the other, a² + b². Another proof comes from a fellow Greek
mathematician Euclid and was also stumbled upon
almost 2,000 years later by twelve-year-old Einstein. This proof divides one right triangle
into two others and uses the principle that if the
corresponding angles of two triangles are the same, the ratio of their sides
is the same, too. So for these three similar triangles, you can write these expressions
for their sides. Next, rearrange the terms. And finally, add the two equations
together and simplify to get ab²+ac²=bc², or a²+b²=c². Here's one that uses tessellation, a repeating geometric pattern
for a more visual proof. Can you see how it works? Pause the video if you'd like some time
to think about it. Here's the answer. The dark gray square is a² and the light gray one is b². The one outlined in blue is c². Each blue outlined square
contains the pieces of exactly one dark and one light gray square, proving the Pythagorean theorem again. And if you'd really like 
to convince yourself, you could build a turntable
with three square boxes of equal depth connected to each other 
around a right triangle. If you fill the largest square with water
and spin the turntable, the water from the large square
will perfectly fill the two smaller ones. The Pythagorean theorem has more
than 350 proofs, and counting, ranging from brilliant to obscure. Can you add your own to the mix?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: From which culture was the earliest recorded usage of the Pythagorean theorem found?
Options: A. Greek, B. Indian, C. Babylonian, D. Egyptian
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What caused the thick gas that blanketed Los Angeles on July 26, 1943? Options: A. Chemical warfare, B. Industrial smog, C. A combination of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides, D. Weather conditions Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary cause of photochemical smog? Options: A. Incomplete combustion of coal, B. Incomplete combustion of gas in motor vehicles, C. A combination of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides, D. Both VOCs and nitrogen oxides react with sunlight to produce secondary pollutants Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the result of the reaction between VOCs, nitrogen oxides, and sunlight in the atmosphere? Options: A. Clean air, B. Photochemical smog, C. Industrial smog, D. The formation of secondary pollutants such as PANs and tropospheric ozone Correct Option: D
Question 4: What location is most prone to industrial smog? Options: A. Cities with high humidity and industrial activities, B. Urban areas with calm winds and dry, warm, sunny weather, C. Cities surrounded by mountains, D. Cities lying in a basin Correct Option: A
Question 5: What phenomenon traps pollution-filled air near the Earth's surface? Options: A. Temperature variation, B. Atmospheric pressure, C. Wind direction, D. Temperature inversion Correct Option: D
Question 6: What secondary pollutants found in photochemical smog can damage and weaken crops? Options: A. PANs and nitrogen oxides, B. VOCs and nitrogen oxides, C. PANs and ground-level ozone, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What was the immediate result of the Great Smog of London in 1952? Options: A. A massive reduction in smog, B. An increase in respiratory deaths, C. A ban on burning coal in certain areas of the city, D. The Great Smog of London caused more than 4,000 respiratory deaths Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the primary goal of the Clean Air Act of 1956? Options: A. To reduce industrial smog, B. To reduce photochemical smog, C. To reduce vehicle emissions, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a possible solution to reduce smog in rapidly developing cities? Options: A. Banning cars from driving for days at a time, B. Considering a shift to mass transit and away from fossil fuels, C. Increasing vehicle emissions, D. Decreasing regulations on vehicle emissions Correct Option: B
Question 10: What are the major health problems posed by smog to young children and older people? Options: A. Eye irritation, B. Respiratory infections, C. Low birth weight and potential birth defects, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the primary source of VOCs in the atmosphere? Options: A. Plants and animals, B. Manmade sources such as solvents, paints, glues, and petroleum, C. Both A and B Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the effect of photochemical smog on crops? Options: A. It makes them more resistant to insects, B. It increases their yield, C. It damages and weakens them, D. It has no effect on crops Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

mathematician Euclid and was also stumbled upon
almost 2,000 years later by twelve-year-old Einstein. This proof divides one right triangle
into two others and uses the principle that if the
corresponding angles of two triangles are the same, the ratio of their sides
is the same, too. So for these three similar triangles, you can write these expressions
for their sides. Next, rearrange the terms. And finally, add the two equations
together and simplify to get ab²+ac²=bc², or a²+b²=c². Here's one that uses tessellation, a repeating geometric pattern
for a more visual proof. Can you see how it works? Pause the video if you'd like some time
to think about it. Here's the answer. The dark gray square is a² and the light gray one is b². The one outlined in blue is c². Each blue outlined square
contains the pieces of exactly one dark and one light gray square, proving the Pythagorean theorem again. And if you'd really like 
to convince yourself, you could build a turntable
with three square boxes of equal depth connected to each other 
around a right triangle. If you fill the largest square with water
and spin the turntable, the water from the large square
will perfectly fill the two smaller ones. The Pythagorean theorem has more
than 350 proofs, and counting, ranging from brilliant to obscure. Can you add your own to the mix?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to the converse of the Pythagorean theorem, stretching a rope knotted into 12 equal segments to form a 3-4-5-segmented triangle would ensure which of the following is created?
Options: A. 30-degree angle, B. 45-degree angle, C. 90-degree angle, D. 120-degree angle
Correct Option: C

Question 2: What is the primary cause of photochemical smog? Options: A. Incomplete combustion of coal, B. Incomplete combustion of gas in motor vehicles, C. A combination of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides, D. Both VOCs and nitrogen oxides react with sunlight to produce secondary pollutants Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the result of the reaction between VOCs, nitrogen oxides, and sunlight in the atmosphere? Options: A. Clean air, B. Photochemical smog, C. Industrial smog, D. The formation of secondary pollutants such as PANs and tropospheric ozone Correct Option: D
Question 4: What location is most prone to industrial smog? Options: A. Cities with high humidity and industrial activities, B. Urban areas with calm winds and dry, warm, sunny weather, C. Cities surrounded by mountains, D. Cities lying in a basin Correct Option: A
Question 5: What phenomenon traps pollution-filled air near the Earth's surface? Options: A. Temperature variation, B. Atmospheric pressure, C. Wind direction, D. Temperature inversion Correct Option: D
Question 6: What secondary pollutants found in photochemical smog can damage and weaken crops? Options: A. PANs and nitrogen oxides, B. VOCs and nitrogen oxides, C. PANs and ground-level ozone, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What was the immediate result of the Great Smog of London in 1952? Options: A. A massive reduction in smog, B. An increase in respiratory deaths, C. A ban on burning coal in certain areas of the city, D. The Great Smog of London caused more than 4,000 respiratory deaths Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the primary goal of the Clean Air Act of 1956? Options: A. To reduce industrial smog, B. To reduce photochemical smog, C. To reduce vehicle emissions, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a possible solution to reduce smog in rapidly developing cities? Options: A. Banning cars from driving for days at a time, B. Considering a shift to mass transit and away from fossil fuels, C. Increasing vehicle emissions, D. Decreasing regulations on vehicle emissions Correct Option: B
Question 10: What are the major health problems posed by smog to young children and older people? Options: A. Eye irritation, B. Respiratory infections, C. Low birth weight and potential birth defects, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the primary source of VOCs in the atmosphere? Options: A. Plants and animals, B. Manmade sources such as solvents, paints, glues, and petroleum, C. Both A and B Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the effect of photochemical smog on crops? Options: A. It makes them more resistant to insects, B. It increases their yield, C. It damages and weakens them, D. It has no effect on crops Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What do Euclid, twelve-year-old Einstein, and American President James Garfield
have in common? They all came up with elegant
proofs for the famous Pythagorean theorem, the rule that says for a right triangle, the square of one side plus
the square of the other side is equal to the square of the hypotenuse. In other words, a²+b²=c². This statement is one of the most
fundamental rules of geometry, and the basis for practical applications, like constructing stable buildings
and triangulating GPS coordinates. The theorem is named for Pythagoras, a Greek philosopher and mathematician
in the 6th century B.C., but it was known more than a
thousand years earlier. A Babylonian tablet from around 1800 B.C.
lists 15 sets of numbers that satisfy the theorem. Some historians speculate 
that Ancient Egyptian surveyors used one such set of numbers, 3, 4, 5,
to make square corners. The theory is that surveyors could stretch
a knotted rope with twelve equal segments to form a triangle with sides of length
3, 4 and 5. According to the converse
of the Pythagorean theorem, that has to make a right triangle, and, therefore, a square corner. And the earliest known 
Indian mathematical texts written between 800 and 600 B.C. state that a rope stretched across
the diagonal of a square produces a square twice as large
as the original one. That relationship can be derived
from the Pythagorean theorem. But how do we know 
that the theorem is true for every right triangle 
on a flat surface, not just the ones these mathematicians
and surveyors knew about? Because we can prove it. Proofs use existing mathematical rules
and logic to demonstrate that a theorem
must hold true all the time. One classic proof often attributed
to Pythagoras himself uses a strategy called 
proof by rearrangement. Take four identical right triangles
with side lengths a and b and hypotenuse length c. Arrange them so that their hypotenuses
form a tilted square. The area of that square is c². Now rearrange the triangles
into two rectangles, leaving smaller squares on either side. The areas of those squares
are a² and b². Here's the key. The total area of 
the figure didn't change, and the areas of the triangles
didn't change. So the empty space in one, c² must be equal to 
the empty space in the other, a² + b². Another proof comes from a fellow Greek
mathematician Euclid and was also stumbled upon
almost 2,000 years later by twelve-year-old Einstein. This proof divides one right triangle
into two others and uses the principle that if the
corresponding angles of two triangles are the same, the ratio of their sides
is the same, too. So for these three similar triangles, you can write these expressions
for their sides. Next, rearrange the terms. And finally, add the two equations
together and simplify to get ab²+ac²=bc², or a²+b²=c². Here's one that uses tessellation, a repeating geometric pattern
for a more visual proof. Can you see how it works? Pause the video if you'd like some time
to think about it. Here's the answer. The dark gray square is a² and the light gray one is b². The one outlined in blue is c². Each blue outlined square
contains the pieces of exactly one dark and one light gray square, proving the Pythagorean theorem again. And if you'd really like 
to convince yourself, you could build a turntable
with three square boxes of equal depth connected to each other 
around a right triangle. If you fill the largest square with water
and spin the turntable, the water from the large square
will perfectly fill the two smaller ones. The Pythagorean theorem has more
than 350 proofs, and counting, ranging from brilliant to obscure. Can you add your own to the mix?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A rope that is stretched across the diagonal of a square is used as the side length of a new square. The new square has ________ area as the original square.
Options: A. The same, B. Half the, C. Twice the, D. Triple the
Correct Option: C
